recipes.title: Steak With Arugula And Orange Salad

winePairing.pairingText: Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon, and Pinot Noir are great choices for Steak. After all, beef and red wine are a classic combination. Generally, leaner steaks go well with light or medium-bodied reds, such as pinot noir or merlot, while fattier steaks can handle a bold red, such as cabernet sauvingnon. The Taltarni Three Monks Cabernet Merlot with a 4 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 15 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Taltarni Three Monks Cabernet Merlot
productMatches.description: Taltarni Three Monks is a Cabernet-Merlot blend that combines two very compatible grape varieties sourced from Victoria. It is set to complement Taltarni's reputation for remarkable Shiraz and Cabernet Sauvignon.The medium-bodied palate is soft, smooth and fills the mouth with ripe berry flavours which are complimented with subtle oak and vanilla. The finish is fresh and clean.Designed for perfect enjoyment on release, it will also reward cellaring. It is an ideal choice matched with lamb veal or your favourite à la Carte meal, such as beef Carpaccio.Blend: 52% cabernet, 48% merlot

recipes.instructions: Directions            Heat 1 teaspoon of the oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Season the steak with  teaspoon salt and  teaspoon pepper.Cook the steak to the desired doneness, 5 to 6 minutes per side for medium-rare. Let rest for 5 minutes before slicing.Meanwhile, in a large bowl, whisk together the vinegar, mustard, remaining tablespoon of oil,  teaspoon salt, and  teaspoon pepper.Cut away the peel and pith of the orange. Working over the vinaigrette bowl, cut out the orange segments, adding them to the bowl as you go.Add the arugula, hearts of palm, and shallot and toss to combine. Serve with the steak and sprinkle with the pomegranate seeds (if using).

steps.step: Heat 1 teaspoon of the oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Season the steak with  teaspoon salt and  teaspoon pepper.Cook the steak to the desired doneness, 5 to 6 minutes per side for medium-rare.
Let rest for 5 minutes before slicing.Meanwhile, in a large bowl, whisk together the vinegar, mustard, remaining tablespoon of oil,  teaspoon salt, and  teaspoon pepper.
Cut away the peel and pith of the orange. Working over the vinaigrette bowl, cut out the orange segments, adding them to the bowl as you go.
Add the arugula, hearts of palm, and shallot and toss to combine.
Serve with the steak and sprinkle with the pomegranate seeds (if using).
